metadata.title: A Short Introduction to MiniNLP

sections.text: In this article, we briefly introduce MiniNLP, a library for processing natural language for clinical narratives. MiniNLP is an experiment in our ideas for efficient and effective processing of medical language. We present the overall design of MiniNLP and its key components and demonstrate its performance in real-world projects.

sections.heading: 2 How MiniNLP Works
sections.text: The general workflow of MiniNLP is similar to that of many other MLP systems. It comprises three stages: pre-processing, entity recognition and semantic analysis. Figure 1 shows some of the most important components of MiniNLP with processing flow mapping.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preprocessing
sections.text: The pre-processing phase includes cleaning artificial formats (such as line breaks imposed by some EHR formatting systems that beautify the display but cut sentences into pieces), detecting sentence boundaries (so that "Diff. Diagnosis" is not halved), and tokenizing. Cut-off detection is not currently part of MiniNLP and should be done outside the library.

sections.heading: 2.3 Semantic Analysis
sections.text: In theory, they are not strong enough to understand all languages [12], but we believe they are good enough to extract information of interest to MLP, such as certainty and modification relationships, from clinical texts. MiniNLP performs semantic analyses by sending the NER result of a sentence one after the other to a pipeline of analyzers. Each analyzer is a finite state machine and focuses on a single task. The state typically includes what the machine has just read, and an interpretation mode, such as negation on / off. The analyzer reads the semantic objects individually and switches the state accordingly, generally through the semantic role of the term, the distance from the previous term, and occasionally the actual text. Let's remember that the identified terms contain grammatical words that are indications for interpreting the text.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Certainty
sections.text: The analysis of certainty includes negation analysis and speculative analysis, assigning Yes, No, or Maybe to the ascription of certainty to each fact semantic object. It uses assignments of meaning and grammatical words to determine meaning and their scope. It also looks at combinations of assignments of meaning and grammatical words, and can merge phrases and modify semantic roles accordingly. For example, "found" is originally a past partition for confirmation in the dictionary, "not" is a negative term, "is" and "was" are positive linkage verbs, "is not" and "is not" are negative auxiliary verbs. Note that the analyst looks at the sequence of identified semantic objects and not the raw words in the sentence, so "has not yet been found."

sections.heading: 2.3.3 Other Analyses
sections.text: MiniNLP uses a generic analyzer for all other modifications. Generic modifications do not nest. Another important analyzer determines whether a part of the set should be ignored by looking for ignore clues such as "check," "assessment," and "comparative diagnosis." The default scope that needs to be ignored is the whole set, but certain semantic objects such as confirmation and negation clues can change that. Another analyzer checks whether the set contains words such as "mother," "" uncle, "etc. (there is a semantic role for relatives). If so, every fact in the set is referred to as family history. New analyzers are actively added to the library when new needs arise. At the end, after all analyses are completed, MiniNLP returns only six objects that are facts that other semantic objects such as places and modifiers can include in their attributes.

sections.heading: 3 Results
sections.text: In a study to detect pulmonary embolism from CTPA reports, a statistical algorithm using information extracted from MiniNLP achieved AUC = 0.998 (cross-validated) in classifying current / absent PE and AUC = 0.986 in detecting subsegmental PE. Other similar studies using MiniNLP include classifying whether patients suffer from rheumatoid arthritis and heart failure. MiniNLP's processing speed is fast enough for real-time analysis. MiniNLP took less than 6 seconds to analyze 10,330 CTPA reports (an 18 megabyte text file on a local drive), equivalent to less than 0.6 ms per report (this is the total time that includes I / O and additional work outside of MiniNLP, such as capturing CTPA reports and post-processing analysis).
